Mahabharata additionally gives particular descriptions of these weapons received from extraterrestrial beings. From a systematic view descriptions of gods and demigods defined in Mahabharata are aliens some distance more advanced in technological know-how than us.

Answer: No, Kshatriyas were not vegetarians, they did dine on meat and wine… Although a few types of meat were abhorred, the Pandavas and Kauravas did have meat in their diet. In fact, there is a specific instance during the battle between Arjuna and Lord Shiva (disguised as a hunter)… The main reason why Arjuna battled the hunter is because he thought the hunter was wrongly taking the prize (The boar that was killed)… Why would Arjuna fight over a boar? Simple, because Boar was a source of food, especially in a jungle where food is hard to find..

Answer: 1 . CloningThe science of cloning was well known and practised during the Mahabharatha times. As per Dr. B.G. Matapurkar, the Kauravas "were products of technology that modern science has not even developed yet". He said that according to the description in Mahabharatha, the Kauravas were created by splitting the single embryo into 100 parts and growing each part in a separate container. In other words, "they not only knew about test-tube babies and embryo splitting but also had the technology to grow human foetuses outside human body2 . Live telecastAs Dhritarashtra was blind but wanted to kn1 . CloningThe science of cloning was well known and practised during the Mahabharatha times. As per Dr. B.G. Matapurkar, the Kauravas "were products of technology that modern science has not even developed yet". He said that according to the description in Mahabharatha, the Kauravas were created by splitting the single embryo into 100 parts and growing each part in a separate container. In other words, "they not only knew about test-tube babies and embryo splitting but also had the technology to grow human foetuses outside human body2 . Live telecastAs Dhritarashtra was blind but wanted to know what was happening at the battlefield, Krishna gifted Sanjay with "Dibya Drishti", so that he could see a “Live Telecast” of “Kurukshetra” and describe that to Dhritarashtra. “Dibya drishti” is analogous to modern television set in the sense that Krishna could not give it directly to Dhristarastra but needed Sanjay.3. AstrasThe function of an Astra is more than that of a missile. It is said that Astras used in Mahabharata probably might have also used technologies of emitting most dangerous rays like Gamma and others, which have exceptional powers to penetrate. Some Astras returns to the person who launches it, for instance, Krishna's Sudharsana Chakra. This may be similar to the reusable missiles which the Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) is working on.Astras were also used for defensive purposes similar to a Tesla Shield which is used to destroy the enemy Astra coming towards it. The modern "Tesla shield" discharges electrical energy and any incoming physical object which hits the shell receives an enormous discharge of that energy and instantly vaporizesSource: Google

Answer: Original Question: How are miracles and significantly advanced technologies different from each other?Advanced technologies are exactly what the name implies, and whilst they mightn’t be understood by many people, they’re all based on eminently workable scientific principles.Miracles are events which are imaginary and only perceived in the mind of someone predisposed to believing they’re real, often based on a belief in a supernatural deity and usually the result of either a coincidence, a misunderstanding, wishful thinking, or confirmation bias - a subconscious tendency to believe in somethinOriginal Question: How are miracles and significantly advanced technologies different from each other?Advanced technologies are exactly what the name implies, and whilst they mightn’t be understood by many people, they’re all based on eminently workable scientific principles.Miracles are events which are imaginary and only perceived in the mind of someone predisposed to believing they’re real, often based on a belief in a supernatural deity and usually the result of either a coincidence, a misunderstanding, wishful thinking, or confirmation bias - a subconscious tendency to believe in something solely because, in the person’s mind, it confirms a previously held belief.Thanks for the A2A.

This invention could remove language barriers and make travelling - and doing business with other cultures – much easier. With these earbuds, someone could be standing in front of you speaking French, and the earbuds will feed you the English translation. You can then hold down your right earbud and speak in English, and your phone will project the French translation from the Pixel's speaker, so the other person can hear. The earbuds can translate 40 different languages!

Answer: The Japanese invented the best torpedo of WW2. It was powered by oxygen tanks and left no visible trail. It could be launched further, higher, and would go faster and longer than any other torpedo. It was theThe Type 93 had a maximum range of 40 km (21.6 nmi; 24.9 mi) at 38 knots (70 km/h; 44 mph) with a 490 kg (1,080 lb)The Japanese invented the best torpedo of WW2. It was powered by oxygen tanks and left no visible trail. It could be launched further, higher, and would go faster and longer than any other torpedo. It was theThe Type 93 had a maximum range of 40 km (21.6 nmi; 24.9 mi) at 38 knots (70 km/h; 44 mph) with a 490 kg (1,080 lb)In the early surface battles of 1942–43, Japanese destroyers and cruisers were able to launch their torpedoes from about 20 km (11 nmi; 12 mi) at the unsuspectingThe Japanese also invented the first intercontinental ballistic bomb. It was essentially a balloon bomb. They released it from Japan and it travelled all the way to America utilising high speed winds where it fell to earth and detonated. The Japanese hoped to use incendiary and biological bombs to cause havoc in America. The bombs caused a few civilian casualties. The Americans soon figured out where the bombs were being deployed from by analyzing the balloon’s sand ballast; they bombed and destroyed the facilities soon after.

Answer: You don’t advance technology as a monolith. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falselYou don’t advance technology as a monolith. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falsely believes nuclear energy to be more dangerous than fossil fuels due to decades of propaganda by idiots.So no. Germany is not the most technologically advanced country. It could be pretty close, but there are major elements of society who dedicate themselves to making sure that Germany uses inferior technology that kills more people, damages the environment more, costs more money, and will cause the total collapse of Earth’s biosphere due to a runaway greenhouse effect. Mostly in the Green Party. Because radiation from nuclear accidents is apparently scarier than way more people dying of regular pollution constantly and the total annihilation of all life on Earth as the oceans boil away.

Getting governments to agree on a single solution is difficult enough with a single government.

Answer: They are bulky and old-fashioned but do not fear because the days of unflattering passport photos are numbered.The out-dated passport could one day be replaced and experts say we have already started transitioning to the ‘cloud passport’ of the future.While the little book is our access key to foreign lands, it is easily lost, stolen and presents some security issues.To replace a lost or stolen passport, the traveller must fill in a form, attend an interview and pay the application fee of $250 on top of the replacement fee of $111.Add this expense to the experience of being trapped in anotherThey are bulky and old-fashioned but do not fear because the days of unflattering passport photos are numbered.The out-dated passport could one day be replaced and experts say we have already started transitioning to the ‘cloud passport’ of the future.While the little book is our access key to foreign lands, it is easily lost, stolen and presents some security issues.To replace a lost or stolen passport, the traveller must fill in a form, attend an interview and pay the application fee of $250 on top of the replacement fee of $111.Add this expense to the experience of being trapped in another country and you’ll see passports are inconvenient to say the least.This photograph stored on the computer chip and in the passports database, allowed passengers to be identified by a biometric system. In this instance, it was facial recognition technology.Tech futurist Morris Miselowski said this was just one step closer to the invisible biometric passport of the future.“I think we will move to the point in the next couple of decades… where we won’t have any passport at all,” he said.“Where our origin, country of residence, birth will be known to people and we’ll be able to move through borders far easier and far quicker.”We already have a lot of the technology needed to make this digital passport a reality, so why are we forced to carry the old-fashioned passport around?Unfortunately, it is not that simple.Not only is it technological, it’s cultural, it’s political, it’s economical, it’s legal, there are all sorts of things we will have to overcome. Mr Miselowski said there were many other factors to consider when implementing a change that would ultimately impact the entire world.Why do we still need to carry passports? | The New Daily

Answer: Recently Ukraine introduced the electronic passport initiative that allows citizens to keep electronic copy of the passport instead of hard copy one.Ukraine is probably the first country in the world that allows to have a proof of identity that could be stored on the user smartphone.Here is how it works.Citizens can download the “Diia” app on the app store which is the portal for all major government services.Ukrainian IDs go digital, biometric passports available in Diia mobile applicationThen citizens can login with electronic key or BankID to confirm their identity.After that the app will dRecently Ukraine introduced the electronic passport initiative that allows citizens to keep electronic copy of the passport instead of hard copy one.Ukraine is probably the first country in the world that allows to have a proof of identity that could be stored on the user smartphone.Here is how it works.Citizens can download the “Diia” app on the app store which is the portal for all major government services.Ukrainian IDs go digital, biometric passports available in Diia mobile applicationThen citizens can login with electronic key or BankID to confirm their identity.After that the app will download their documents like passport, driving license, etc.To make sure the ID is not fake one the app is generating one time QR code that could be scanned by the relevant authorities (police, banks, government services, etc.) and will confirm the authenticity of the document.Government recently approved regulations which make smartphone IDs as valid as paper one.Ukraine plans are even more ambitious.The next goal is to introduce electronic foreign passport and negotiate treaties with other countries that will allow citizens to travel internationally without any paper documents.Isn't that cool?
